pull.title: mempool: Loading progress added for dumping mempool transactions to disk
pull.body:
Sometimes when shutting off bitcoind it can take a while to dump the mempool transaction onto the disk so
this change adds additional logging to the `DumpMempool` method in `kernel/mempool_persist.cpp`

Similar to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29227 this 
 - adds a maximum of 10 new log lines
 - logs the progress for every 10%

This is in response to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29227#issuecomment-1893375082

The logs will now look like this
```
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z scheduler thread exit
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Dumping 468 mempool transactions to disk...
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 10% (tried 47, 421 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 20% (tried 94, 374 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 30% (tried 141, 327 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 40% (tried 188, 280 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 50% (tried 234, 234 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 60% (tried 281, 187 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 70% (tried 328, 140 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 80% (tried 375, 93 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Progress dumping mempool transactions to disk: 90% (tried 422, 46 remaining)
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Writing 0 unbroadcast transactions to disk.
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Dumped mempool: 0.000986089s to copy, 0.03434s to dump
2024-02-07T13:03:55Z Flushed fee estimates to fee_estimates.dat.
```

A summary of reviews will appear here.
Why is this needed? A progress log for something that takes less than a second does not sound useful

> Why is this needed? A progress log for something that takes less than a second does not sound useful

This is in response to this comment https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29227#pullrequestreview-1817064507 
the logs I posted in the description are from testnet I can run this on mainnet to get the time it takes on shutdown there

verification.payload:
tree 4f92947e2f1d1be149bd9e65d4dea8508203e730
parent 11b436a66af3ceaebb0f907878715f331516a0bc
author kevkevin <oapallikunnel@gmail.com> 1707307651 -0600
committer kevkevin <oapallikunnel@gmail.com> 1707313460 -0600

mempool: Loading progress added for dumping mempool transactions to disk

events.message: mempool: Loading progress added for dumping mempool transactions to disk

events.body: The delay is probably from leveldb, but it would be good to first check

> Why is this needed? A progress log for something that takes less than a second does not sound useful

I agree that logging the detailed progress in % is a bit overkill, but IMHO a single line "Dumping xyz mempool transactions to disk..." would still make sense. The "less than a second" data point seems to be closer to best-case, I have one machine here where dumping a full default-sized mempool takes more than 10 seconds.

> 10 seconds.

Sure, it may take longer than one second, depending on the hardware and its size. However,

* *Loading* a mempool can take hours, depending on the hardware and its size.
* *Loading* is done in a background thread, so other stuff is going on and logged at the same time.

Shutdown should be single-threaded, so the debug log should contain the last timestamp, which is enough to derive how long it took to dump the mempool, or whether it is still ongoing. I don't expect anyone to poll the debug log every second to see an update on the progress.

> IMHO a single line "Dumping xyz mempool transactions to disk..." would still make sense.

Agree, if there isn't such a log line right now, it could make sense to add it.

> logging the detailed progress in % is a bit overkill

+1 to @theStack's comment. Logging the start and end would be sufficient, no need for the 10% increments.
